bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, March 3, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses his report on the true location of Camp Lazear. He requests additional information from Webster.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Royal S. Webster, March 3, 1941
div1.opener:
Copy to Moran
3/6/41 Sent Mile
Post etc
March 3, 1941
Mr. Royal S. Webster
Divisional Engineer
Ferrocarriles Unidos de la Habana
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Webster:
div1.p:
I hope to visit Havana again about April 5-12, and have been trying
to finish the report on the true location of Camp Lazear which Dr. Ramos,
Minister of Defense, asked me to prepare for him. I have documented this re-
port with about fifty exhibits (photographs, maps and photostated letters). I
have just finished the preliminary copy. Unfortunately I have to have it checked
over by Generals Kean and Truby and Dr. Cooke in this country so I have only one
copy to send to Havana. This one I am sending to Mr. Moran to check over and to
have it approved by Senora Rojas and by Senor Pogolotti whom I have quoted exten-
sively. I hope he can also show it to you and to Dr. Agramonte's daughter, but
I hope it can be returned to me within a week so that I can get my report in Dr.
Ramos' hands about March 15.

Whether Mr. Moran gets the preliminary copy to you or not I will see
to it that you see the final copy as I believe it will interest you. Furthermore
I want you to see how helpful your information and maps have been. Although I
have gotten from you the information I wanted it is not stated in your letter in
such a way as to be entirely clear without copies of the maps. Could you do me
a real favor? I would appreciate it greatly if you would send me at your very
earliest convenience, if possible by air mail, a short statement giving the ages
of the railroad track branches concerned in our discussions, with a free hand
pencil drawing right in the context of your letter. I will have photostated
copies made of this letter and, if you will permit me, will use it as one of
the exhibits in my report to Dr. Ramos. Will you permit me to append some
such statement as I'd like to have?
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
